PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A note of explanation to the person completing this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. In extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ... Johan T. Lee

2. Your address ... Kyle, Sask.

3. Date ... June 3, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Neslerud, Soran Akerhus, Norway

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   H.J. Lee Tanner & Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   May, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Askim, Norway until arriving here.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   17 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To obtain homestead land

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    My father was in the States in the '79 and '80's. He advised me to go to Canada because it was a new country.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct, as you have given it, please say so. If you would rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Johan T. Lee
   Address: Kyle, Sask.
   Date: June 4, 1952

2. Your address: N.E., S.W., N.W., S.E., etc.

3. Date: June 4, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, etc.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Johan T. Lee, Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   May, 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Askim, Norway until arriving here.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age.)
   17 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   To obtain home of land.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)
    My father was in the States in the '70s and '80s. He advised me to go to Canada because it was a new country.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Some considered it a wise move and others thought different.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
    Travelled by myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Oceanliner and railroad.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
    meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
    Just the meeting of other nationalities, mainly in Winnipeg,
    and seeing the hundreds of people standing in line waiting
    for employment.
    The going wages was $2.00 a day at that time and I paid
    $4.50 a week for room and board.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    The first place I worked was railroad construction work
    between Rushlake and Atkins. There was no farmer west of
    Cairns when I went West.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    S.E.14 21 16 W3rd.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
    I worked in a store in Oslo. Construction work and harvesting
    until I started farming.
2.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Some considered it a wise move and others thought different.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or others)?

13. What mode of transportation did you use?

Oceanliner and railroad.

14. What incidents of the Journey East do you remember? (People you met on the train, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences etc.)

Just the meeting of other nationalities mainly in Winnipeg, and seeing the hundreds of people standing in line waiting for employment. We paid $5.00 a day at that time and I paid.

The going wages was $8.50 a day.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

The first place I worked was railroad construction work between Ruhleke and Atkins. There was no farmer west of Carins when I went West.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

S.E.14, 21, 16 W.R.D.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked in a store in Oslo. Construction work and harvesting until I started farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About three times a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?
    My sister came and then Father.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
    My sister, Thea Hecla came in 1908, and Father
    came in 1909 and both settled in Kyle, Sask.,
    In 1909 my brother, Sigur, came and he is now living
    at Minnitaki, Ontario.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
    Driving oxen and crossing the Saskatchewan river at the
    Saskatchewan Landing by ferry. Hauling grain by team of horses
    to Swift Current up until 1912 after that I hauled to
    Pennant.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    In 1905 I went to B.C. for a few months working in a sawmill
    at Arrowhead. Then the next trip was the Grain Growers
    Convention in Regina, Sask., in 1906. In 1925, in the fall,
    I went to Vancouver to visit, and in June, 1926 I went to
    Camrose, Alta., to a Lutheran Church Convention. I travelled
    by railroad on all these trips.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My sister came and then Father.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My sister, Tina Heals came in 1909 and Father came in 1910 and both settled in Kyle's Creek. In 1929 my brother Glen came and he is now living at Minnitaki, Ontario.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Driving oxen and crossing the Saskatchewan river at the Saskatchewan Landing by ferry, hauling grain by team of horses to Swift Current up until 1912 after that I hauled to Fernie.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How many times?

In 1905 I went to B.C. for a few months working in a sawmill at Arrowsmith. Then the next trip was the 1906 General Convention in Regina. In 1908 I went to Vancouver to visit and in June 1909 I went to Caribou, Maine, for a United Church Convention. I travelled by railroad for all these trips.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   My brother-in-law, Thor E. Hesla, bought the first one, a Ford, in 1913.

26. If you owned a car before 1912, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Swift Current, Sask., 55 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   In 1910 some local farmers began local stores in the district, as one sold out another opened a business up until about 1926 when Kyle Hamlet began.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Every mail day which was once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   In 1926 the beginning of Kyle.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1910 I began ordering my winter clothing, mainly.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Had to stay after buying my land because I was too poor to do otherwise and the land was so cheap at that time it didn't pay to sell.
25. When was the first car used in the community?

My brother-in-law, Thor E. Halsbo, bought the first one, a Ford, in 1913.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, what did you buy it for? What makes it?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

Gulf, Current, Baaske, 55 miles.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?
About 25% left because of it being too far to market and they didn't find it paying.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
Very few.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.
I was councillor in 1928 for Municipality of Lacadena.
I joined the Free Masons in 1916 and the 1926 I joined the Eastern Star.
My brother-in-law, Thor E. Besla became councillor for the Municipality of Lacadena about 1916 and held that position until the late 1940's.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
1907 first threshing machine with stationary engine, C. Schoberg.
1910 first tractor, C. Schoberg (deceased)
1912 Lutheran Church was organized, Sec 11-21-16 W3rd. The Church built in 1915. Quite a landmark.
1912 Horse Butte School built first school in the district.
location, Sec. 33-20-16 W3rd.
1912 Lutheran Ladies Aid organized and still operating.
1900 First homesteader, Harry White (deceased), a rancher.
1905 First farmers - C. Schoberg, Josh Turner, Edwin Larson.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
Horse Butte School District, 1912, named by formation of hills "Butte", by the first ranchers.
Kyleville Post Office, 1908, Sec. 31-21-16 W3rd, owned by the Kyle family. Later moved to Kyle.
Village of Kyle, 1920, named after the Kyle Family.
Bonepile Hills, named 1908 by a pile of bones about eight feet high left there by the Indians.
Matador Hills, about 1903, owned by a company formed by the Matador's.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

I family have a Family Register goes back to 1916, my Fathers Diary, these both are written in Norwegian.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? Yes, but I'm leaving for 3 months visit to Norway the first of July.
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The growth and improvements of the town of Kyle.
The combine thresher.
The Wheat Board.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.
